title: I love logic, philosophical or mathematical. Should I pursue a major in mathematics or philosophy? - Quora
tags: Advice About College and University Majors

response.answer_text: Math. The more hard core math you know the more clear your eventual philosophical thinking of math will be. Don't miss this opportunity to formally study what is a real number and what's an infinite set. People who don't take undergrad math major courses simply aren't well positioned to reason philosophically about math. You should go as technically deep as you possibly can, then the philosophy will make a lot more sense. In particular, although set theory is the foundation of twentieth century math, there are alternatives starting to percolate at the research level. Homotopy type theory, intuitionist logic, topos theory. There's a lot of influence from computer science into axiomatic systems and formal proof systems. All these things influence the modern philosophy of math. In short, go as hard core as you can into the math and computer science. You can't really philosophize about things you don't know.

At the undergraduate level, taking a double major in both math and philosophy is a good option. Having the experience with both perspectives will be helpful if you decide to go on to graduate school and pursue an academic career. Or if you decide to seek other employment, the wide range of skills reflected by both majors will again be helpful.  If you have to choose only one major, philosophy or computer science might be better choices considering your interests than math. Math departments rarely offer much pure logic. The closest you might get is a course in set theory, but even that is rarely seen below the graduate level.

“I love logic, philosophical or mathematical. Should I pursue a major in mathematics or philosophy?” There's a saying: “You want fries with that?” It's much more commonly said by those with philosophy degrees than those with math degrees.
Do mathematics. Most graduate students in mathematics can understand philosophy journal papers; most graduate students in philosophy can't understand a single sentence in a math journal paper.

Mathematics is more useful. (And more interesting from my perspective.)Also math is the truth. Philosophy is only a collection of people's opinions. I took some symbolic logic and it is very cool. But maybe not as useful as math when it comes to the job world.

I did pure Philosophy. If I had been better at Maths, I'd have been better at Philosophy. But Language is really my thing. In the real world, employers consider maths to be more 'hardcore', mainly because few of them understand the rigours of philosophical thinking, so it opens more doors. Maths for the future, Philosophy for the mind buzz...
